risks.Risk Description: A ubiquitous concern, with 78% of respondents indicating cybersecurity is a high or very high risk in their organizations.

Risk Driver.Driver Description: Driven by the increasing reliance on technology across organizations.

risks.Trend: Audit plans and frequency data indicate that cybersecurity remains a focal, sustained area of concern compared to pre-2019 levels.

risks.Risk Description: Identified as one of the top three technology‐driven risks based on survey responses.

Risk Driver.Driver Description: Resulting from the broad integration of information technology systems across organizations.

risks.Trend: Not explicitly detailed; audit allocations indicate IT is consistently monitored but without a clear upward or downward trend.
risks.Contextual Variations: Publicly traded organizations tend to rate IT risk lower compared to financial services organizations.

risks.Risk Description: Ranked as the third highest risk area after cybersecurity and IT, yet audited at a lower frequency than its risk rating suggests.

Risk Driver.Driver Description: Heightened by the frequent use of third parties for IT services, which increases exposure to external risks.

risks.Trend: Not explicitly detailed; however, a significant audit frequency gap (33 percentage points lower than risk perception) is noted.
risks.Contextual Variations: Privately held organizations view third‐party risk as higher (second highest risk) compared to publicly traded organizations, which tend to rate it lower.

risks.Risk Description: A key focus area with almost 90% of respondents integrating fraud considerations into their general audits.
Pertains to internal controls over financial reporting – including SOX testing and compliance – with allocation variations based on SOX implementation.

Risk Driver.Driver Description: SOX implementation and related regulatory mandates drive heightened attention to financial reporting controls.

risks.Trend: Audit data show that financial reporting allocations are higher than the perceived risk in some cases and have recently decreased in publicly traded organizations.
risks.Contextual Variations: Publicly traded organizations allocate around 31% to financial reporting, while privately held organizations with SOX implementation show much higher allocation compared to those without SOX.

risks.Risk Description: Risk associated with cost and expense reduction measures, noted as being significantly higher among nonprofit organizations.
risks.Trend: Audit plan allocations for cost/expense reduction have been trending upward since 2019.
risks.Contextual Variations: Nonprofit organizations exhibit a markedly higher risk rating for cost/expense reduction compared to other sectors.

risks.Risk Description: Relates to sustainability and non-financial reporting concerns, with over 60% of respondents from publicly traded organizations rating this risk as moderate, high, or very high.
risks.Trend: Audit allocations to sustainability/non-financial reporting have shown increases in certain sectors since 2019.
risks.Contextual Variations: Publicly traded organizations tend to rate this risk as moderate to high, while about 52% of public sector respondents consider it a significant risk.

risks.Risk Description: Pertains to risks related to organizational governance and culture, with a notable 20 percentage point gap observed between perceived risk and audit frequency.
